byline.contributor: Dan Levin reported from Tianjin, and Javier C. Hernández from Hong Kong. Andrew Jacobs contributed reporting from Tianjin. Adam Wu, Yufan Huang and Mia Li contributed research.
byline.original: By DAN LEVIN and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

abstract: Chinese authorities do not explain thousands of dead fish on banks of Haihe River, less than four miles from site in port city of Tianjin where series of deadly explosions destroyed warehouse filled with toxic chemicals, killing more than 100 people; photos of masses of dead fish are posted on Chinese social media, increasing public fears over chemical contamination, despite government assurances of environmental safety in area.
lead_paragraph: The discovery came as officials said that wastewater runoff near the site contained hundreds of times as much cyanide as allowed by law.

headline.main: New Concerns in Tianjin Blast After Dead Fish Are Found
headline.print_headline: Fish Die Off in Chinese River Near Blast Site

snippet: The discovery came as officials said that wastewater runoff near the site contained hundreds of times as much cyanide as allowed by law.
